content:
Margaret, if you click on Windows File Explorer, look at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles. If this folder exists, then click any folder inside it and look for a file called abook.sqlite. That would be the addressbook. If File Explorer does not let you view the folders, you can click View>Show>Hidden items in File Explorer. The folders will be there if all you did was uninstall Thunderbird, but there is a final prompt on an uninstall on whether to keep data, so it's possible you may have deleted it.

If you have done a new install, there may be more than one folder in the Profiles folder, so look for the oldest and largest abook.sqlite. Let me know if you need more assistance.
creator: davidsk

content:
Perhaps the subject line wasn't enough of a lead-in to the first paragraph. So, from the top:

1) I had 3 Apple-mail email accounts which were misbehaving 2) I saw that Thunderbird, which I used to use a long time ago, had come back to life. So I switched two of my email accounts over to Thunderbird Result: Whoops, I could only send mail on a single Thunderbird email account. The second email account simply wouldn't send

3) I looked on Thunderbird's support pages and realized I was not alone and that the "answer" seemed to be to delete the existing Thunderbird email accounts and start from scratch. (Which I refuse to do.) Result: For the moment I'm returning to Apple mail as the problem I had been having has gone away

Observation: The "automatic" setup for Thunderbird works like a charm, so long as you want ONE email account. If you want more than a single email account, then a set-up recipe or other documentation would be lovely as it would prevent users from screwing up their settings

creator: davidsk

content: For what it's worth, Thunderbird is excellent, but only as a client that does what we want. It does not think; it sends requests for mail to the assigned mail servers and waits for the response. That's as intelligent as it gets. It's like sending a child with an envelope to the post office to deposit in the outgoing mail slot. Whatever happens next is due to the post office. Same goes for Thunderbird. I regularly see posts from users, complaining about decisions that Thunderbird makes. Yet it does not; it is a simple messenger. An excellent one, in that it reliably tells you whatever info it received back from server. But switching servers? It's not that creative. :) Anyway, I'm glad that all worked well for you.
creator: davidsk

content:
jMac said
I think that I need to completely uninstall TB Something went wrong on one of my computers, and it couldn't connect to the server. It works on my other computer.

And uninstalling and reinstalling is going to do what exactly?

I decided to uninstall TB that had the problem. I did that, but when I reinstalled it, it had all of the same settings and problems. I used RevoUnstaller. because it said When I reinstalled it, all of the stuff and the problem were back. What is the best way to fix this?

Toss the Revo product in the bin. Everyone I have seen on this forum that has used it has made their issues worse by using it. I have recommended folks reinstall Thunderbird to fix a problem perhaps 10 time a year over the last 10 years and that is always around messed up updates (platform version incompatibilities) or system integration issues.

Thunderbird is specifically designed as a cross platform program to not use the windows registry for general application settings and the retain the user profile between installs. So a reinstall is basically going to change nothing.

By using third party uninstallers you get the satisfaction of doing it your way, but you also get the burden of recovering any data you deleted in the process that you wanted to keep (your profile with mail and contacts particularly.) Revo is a nuclear response and like all nuclear responsed has significant fall out and collateral damage. Don't do it.

If through some miracle you still have you original setup post reinstall I don't know how but you are saying things that makes me think you did not do a full removal with revo. What exactly is the issue you are trying to fix?

This weeks apparent popular issue in this forum is Nortons antivirus. I have had a number of folk that could not get mail and and being warned of potential security issues ahead in Thunderbird. Removing Norton fixed all of their issues with Thunderbird. However as you have offered no information at all about your apparent problems I am guessing big time here.

So what is the actual issue. Beyond the fact you have not manged to remove everything and lost all your mail and contact data in the process.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: JudsonMcCranie

content: One of the strengths (my opinion) of Thunderbird is that, as Matt indicated, it keeps settings separate from the code and from the registry - which means all of that is in your profile. When thunderbird is uninstalled, it politely leaves the profile. If you want a full reinstall from scratch, you need to delete the profile after the uninstall. To do that, first ininstall thunderbird, and then locate c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird and delete the thunderbird folder. Now, when you reinstall thunderbird, all will be new.
creator: davidsk

content:
designer5 said
This topic was closed but the Bug was never fixed for Mac.

You have one previous topic, and it is not about spelling https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1372578

The problem is, sometimes a spelling is correct as intended or not, depending upon its context in the email body. But the Spell Check Window covers that up as it blocks the middle of the email body. It can't be moved in Thunderbird for Mac. A previous post - now archived - suggested a left click on the (spell check?) window title area would allow moving the window. But that only works on ... Windows ... because it certainly does NOT work on a Mac. No click-drag, left or right, resulted in un-anchoring the spell check window from the center of the email body. One example is when I used the word Add-ons. The spell check stopped at "ons", wanting to correct it to "one". If "ons" was by itself, I could see that. But I couldn't know that it referred to "ons" from Add-ons because the spell-check window covered that text.

I don't use anything apple, so I can't try it for you. Nor do I use that ugly dialog. I have spell check as I type enabled and it offers the corrections as a list on a right click menu.

if you still can not move the dialog by clicking the title bar, or using the other mac tools I suggest you try restarting in safe mode/ troubleshooting mode from the help menu. If you still have an issue you should probably file a bug report in bugzilla
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Perhaps ask comcast why they blocked you on that IP address.

Note this well. The IP address used by your desktop computer is allocated by the provider of the internet service. That used by your phone is allocated by the phone service provider and they can not be the same. So the fact that you are blocked on one and not the other is basically not relevant here as the error is about a specific IP address.

But I am confused are you just starting using Thunderbird with that address? Or have you had an issue and erroneously tried to fix it by adding the account again?
creator: MattAuSupport
